creator: RonM9
title: 3 Minute Game Timer, a Deep Sleeping ATtiny85 Digispark
description: This project creates a small, low-power timer using an ATtiny85 Digispark board, intended for use with games. It utilizes LEDs and a buzzer to indicate the passage of time and enters a deep sleep mode to conserve battery life.
steps: Cut the three leads coming out of the 78M05 voltage regulator on the Digispark board to reduce power consumption.
Cut the trace between the power-on LED and its supply resistor to further reduce power consumption, but without removing either component.
(Optional) Cut the trace to the resistor R3 used to pull up the PB3 signal. If you do this, you need to solder in a diode (1N4148) from the '5v' line to the end of R3 you cut the trace by.
Wire the LEDs, resistor, tilt switch, and buzzer directly to the Digispark board.
Mount the tilt switch so it is normally open when the container is set how you want it while it is timing and during storage.
Hot glue a spring metal clip inside a container's top to hold the assembly in place.
File the USB edge of the board so it can be wedged in the clip more easily, and wrap a piece of paper over the edge of the board before pressing it in to prevent shorts.
Potentially file off the corner of the buzzer to fit it into the container, and secure the battery holder to the PCB with hot glue.
In the Arduino IDE, select the board as “Digispark (Default – 16.5mhz)” when programming the MCU.
Upload the provided code to the Digispark board.
Flip the unit over and put it back up right to start the timer period. This will be marked by three quick flashes and chirps.
Observe the LED flashes and buzzer chirps to track the passage of each minute, per the code's instructions.
Stop the timing process by turning the timer back over.
